Lebesgue-Radon-Nikodym derivative, measure theory

Suppose μ\muμ and ν\nuν are finite positive (regular) Borel measures on Rn\R^nRn. Prove the existence and uniqueness of the Lebesgue decomposition: There are a unique pair of positive Borel measures μa\mu_aμa​ and μs\mu_sμs​ so that

μ=μa+μs,μa≪ν,andμs⊥ν.\mu = \mu_a + \mu_s, \quad \mu_a \ll \nu, \quad\text{and}\quad \mu_s \perp \nu.μ=μa​+μs​,μa​≪ν,andμs​⊥ν.

That is, μa\mu_aμa​ is absolutely continuous to ν\nuν, while μs\mu_sμs​ is mutually singular to ν\nuν.
Solution.

Let B\mathcal{B}B denote the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra and set

M=sup⁡ {μ(B)∣B∈B and ν(B)=0}.M = \sup\,\set{\mu\p{B} \mid B \in \mathcal{B} \text{ and } \nu\p{B} = 0}.M=sup{μ(B)∣B∈B and ν(B)=0}.

Observe that for any B∈BB \in \mathcal{B}B∈B, ν(B)≤μ(X)<∞\nu\p{B} \leq \mu\p{X} < \inftyν(B)≤μ(X)<∞, so taking supremums, we see M≤μ(X)<∞M \leq \mu\p{X} < \inftyM≤μ(X)<∞. Hence, for each n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, there exists Bn∈BB_n \in \mathcal{B}Bn​∈B with ν(Bn)=0\nu\p{B_n} = 0ν(Bn​)=0 and μ(Bn)≥M−1n\mu\p{B_n} \geq M - \frac{1}{n}μ(Bn​)≥M−n1​. If we set A=⋃n=1∞BnA = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_nA=⋃n=1∞​Bn​, then

ν(A)≤∑n=1∞ν(Bn)=0  ⟹  μ(A)≤M,\nu\p{A} \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \nu\p{B_n} = 0 \implies \mu\p{A} \leq M,ν(A)≤n=1∑∞​ν(Bn​)=0⟹μ(A)≤M,

by definition of MMM. Moreover,

μ(A)=μ(⋃n=1∞Bn)=lim⁡N→∞μ(⋃n=1NBn)≥lim⁡N→∞(M−1N)=M,\mu\p{A} = \mu\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_n} = \lim_{N\to\infty} \mu\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^N B_n} \geq \lim_{N\to\infty} \p{M - \frac{1}{N}} = M,μ(A)=μ(n=1⋃∞​Bn​)=N→∞lim​μ(n=1⋃N​Bn​)≥N→∞lim​(M−N1​)=M,

so μ(A)=M\mu\p{A} = Mμ(A)=M, i.e., the supremum is attained. For B∈BB \in \mathcal{B}B∈B, define

μa(B)=μ(B∖A)andμs(B)=μ(B∩A).\mu_a\p{B} = \mu\p{B \setminus A} \quad\text{and}\quad \mu_s\p{B} = \mu\p{B \cap A}.μa​(B)=μ(B∖A)andμs​(B)=μ(B∩A).

Since μ\muμ is a finite Borel measure, it's clear that these are also finite Borel measures. We will show that they satisfy the given properties:

If ν(B)=0\nu\p{B} = 0ν(B)=0, then ν(A∪B)=0\nu\p{A \cup B} = 0ν(A∪B)=0 as well so

M=μ(A)≤μ(A∪B)≤MM = \mu\p{A} \leq \mu\p{A \cup B} \leq MM=μ(A)≤μ(A∪B)≤M

by definition of MMM, so these are all equalities. Hence, by measurability of BBB,

M=μ(A∪B)=μ(A)+μ(E∖A)=M+μa(B)  ⟹  μa(B)=0,M = \mu\p{A \cup B} = \mu\p{A} + \mu\p{E \setminus A} = M + \mu_a\p{B} \implies \mu_a\p{B} = 0,M=μ(A∪B)=μ(A)+μ(E∖A)=M+μa​(B)⟹μa​(B)=0,

so μa≪ν\mu_a \ll \nuμa​≪ν. On the other hand, Rn=A∪Ac\R^n = A \cup A^\compRn=A∪Ac, A∩Ac=∅A \cap A^\comp = \emptysetA∩Ac=∅, ν(A)=0\nu\p{A} = 0ν(A)=0, and μs(Ac)=μs(∅)=0\mu_s\p{A^\comp} = \mu_s\p{\emptyset} = 0μs​(Ac)=μs​(∅)=0, so μs⊥ν\mu_s \perp \nuμs​⊥ν. Finally, by measurability of AAA, μ(B)=μ(B∖A)+μ(B∩A)=μa(B)+μs(B)\mu\p{B} = \mu\p{B \setminus A} + \mu\p{B \cap A} = \mu_a\p{B} + \mu_s\p{B}μ(B)=μ(B∖A)+μ(B∩A)=μa​(B)+μs​(B) for any BBB, which proves existence.

It remains to show uniqueness. Suppose μ=μa+μs=μa′+μs′\mu = \mu_a + \mu_s = \mu_a' + \mu_s'μ=μa​+μs​=μa′​+μs′​ are two Lebesgue decompositions of μ\muμ. Then μa−μa′=μs′−μs\mu_a - \mu_a' = \mu_s' - \mu_sμa​−μa′​=μs′​−μs​. If ν(B)=0\nu\p{B} = 0ν(B)=0, then by absolute continuity,

0=μa(B)−μa′(B)=μs(B)−μs′(B)  ⟹  μs(B)=μs′(B).0 = \mu_a\p{B} - \mu_a'\p{B} = \mu_s\p{B} - \mu_s'\p{B} \implies \mu_s\p{B} = \mu_s'\p{B}.0=μa​(B)−μa′​(B)=μs​(B)−μs′​(B)⟹μs​(B)=μs′​(B).

On the other hand, if ν(B)>0\nu\p{B} > 0ν(B)>0, then let A,A′A, A'A,A′ be such that μs(A)=0\mu_s\p{A} = 0μs​(A)=0 and ν(Ac)=0\nu\p{A^\comp} = 0ν(Ac)=0; μs′(A′)=0\mu_s'\p{A'} = 0μs′​(A′)=0 and ν(A′c)=0\nu\p{A'^\comp} = 0ν(A′c)=0, which exist since μs,μs′⊥ν\mu_s, \mu_s' \perp \nuμs​,μs′​⊥ν. If we set A′′=A∩A′A'' = A \cap A'A′′=A∩A′, then μs(A′′)=μs′(A′′)=0\mu_s\p{A''} = \mu_s'\p{A''} = 0μs​(A′′)=μs′​(A′′)=0 and ν(A′′c)=0\nu\p{A''^\comp} = 0ν(A′′c)=0. Hence,

μs(B)=μs(B∖A′′)andμs′(B)=μs′(B∖A′′),\mu_s\p{B} = \mu_s\p{B \setminus A''} \quad\text{and}\quad \mu_s'\p{B} = \mu_s'\p{B \setminus A''},μs​(B)=μs​(B∖A′′)andμs′​(B)=μs′​(B∖A′′),

but ν(B∖A′′)=0\nu\p{B \setminus A''} = 0ν(B∖A′′)=0, so by absolutely continuity again, μa(B∖A′′)\mu_a\p{B \setminus A''}μa​(B∖A′′). Thus,

0=μa(B∖A′′)−μa′(B∖A′′)=μs(B∖A′′)−μs′(B∖A′′)=μs(B)−μs′(B)  ⟹  μs(B)=μs′(B).\begin{aligned} 0 &= \mu_a\p{B \setminus A''} - \mu_a'\p{B \setminus A''} \\ &= \mu_s\p{B \setminus A''} - \mu_s'\p{B \setminus A''} \\ &= \mu_s\p{B} - \mu_s'\p{B} \\ \implies \mu_s\p{B} &= \mu_s'\p{B}. \end{aligned}0⟹μs​(B)​=μa​(B∖A′′)−μa′​(B∖A′′)=μs​(B∖A′′)−μs′​(B∖A′′)=μs​(B)−μs′​(B)=μs′​(B).​

Hence, μs=μs′  ⟹  μa=μa′\mu_s = \mu_s' \implies \mu_a = \mu_a'μs​=μs′​⟹μa​=μa′​, so the decompositions are the same.
